class: Sodium Channel Blocker - Class IA antidysrhythmic
mechanism: Blocks sodium channels in the cells of the cardiac conduction system
indications: Acute treatment of ventricular cardiac arrhythmias
contraindications: Baseline prolonged QT interval, Hypersensitivity; Severe sinoatrial node dysfunction, aortic stenosis, or intraventricular blocks

class: Sodium Channel Blocker - Class IA antidysrhythmic
mechanism: Blocks sodium channels in the cells of the cardiac conduction system
indications: Acute treatment of ventricular cardiac arrhythmias
contraindications: Baseline prolonged QT interval, systemic lupus erythematosus, hypersensitivity; Severe sinoatrial node dysfunction, aortic stenosis, or intraventricular blocks
education: Report hypotension, signs of lupus-like syndrome, or unusual bruising/bleeding

class: Sodium Channel Blocker - Class IB antidysrhythmic
mechanism: Blocks sodium channels in the cells of the cardiac conduction system
indications: Acute treatment of ventricular cardiac arrhythmias
contraindications: Severe sinoatrial node dysfunction, aortic stenosis, or intraventricular blocks

class: Sodium Channel Blocker - Class IB antidysrhythmic
mechanism: Blocks sodium channels in the cells of the cardiac conduction system
indications: Acute treatment of ventricular cardiac arrhythmias
contraindications: Severe sinoatrial node dysfunction, aortic stenosis, or intraventricular blocks
education: Report signs and symptoms of hepatic toxicity

class: Sodium Channel Blocker - Class IC antidysrhythmic
mechanism: Blocks sodium channels in the cells of the cardiac conduction system
indications: Acute treatment of ventricular cardiac arrhythmias
contraindications: Severe sinoatrial node dysfunction, aortic stenosis, or intraventricular blocks
education: Risk of 1:1 AV conduction in atrial fibrillation or flutter

class: Sodium Channel Blocker - Class IC antidysrhythmic
mechanism: Blocks sodium channels in the cells of the cardiac conduction system
indications: Acute treatment of ventricular cardiac arrhythmias
contraindications: Severe sinoatrial node dysfunction, aortic stenosis, or intraventricular blocks
education: Report signs of infection due to agranulocytosis

mechanism: Acts as a beta-1 receptor antagonist in cardiac tissue, slowing pacing from the sinoatrial node and conduction through the atrioventricular node
indications: Intraoperative and postoperative tachycardia and hypertension
education: Change positions slowly to avoid orthostatic hypotension

education: Change positions slowly to avoid orthostatic hypotension

class: Potassium channel blocker - Class III antidysrhythmic
mechanism: Blocks the potassium channels responsible for repolarization of the cell, leading to a prolonged action potential and prolonged refractoriness
contraindications: Severe renal impairment (creatinine clearance less than 20 mL/min)
interactions: drugs that prolong the QT interval

class: Potassium channel blocker - Class III antidysrhythmic
mechanism: Blocks the potassium channels responsible for repolarization of the cell, leading to a prolonged action potential and prolonged refractoriness
contraindications: Severe renal impairment (creatinine clearance less than 20 mL/min)

contraindications: Severe renal impairment (creatinine clearance less than 20 mL/min)

class: Calcium Channel Blockers - Class IV antidysrhythmic
mechanism: Inhibits the calcium channel in cardiac tissue and blood vessels, leading to decreased conduction through the atrioventricular node and vasodilation
contraindications: Sick sinus syndrome (unless client has ventricular pacemaker)

class: Calcium Channel Blockers - Class IV antidysrhythmic
mechanism: Inhibits the calcium channel in cardiac tissue and blood vessels, leading to decreased conduction through the atrioventricular node and vasodilation
contraindications: Sick sinus syndrome (unless client has ventricular pacemaker)

mechanism: Acetylcholine receptor antagonist, thus decreasing parasympathetic or vagal regulation of the heart rate
Inhibits the sodium-potassium ATPase pump, increasing intracellular calcium to strengthen myocardial contraction; enhances parasympathetic activity, slowing heart rate
indications: Heart failure with persistent symptoms despite optimal therapy
education: Monitor serum digoxin levels (therapeutic: 0.5–2.0 ng/mL); assess apical pulse before administration; report signs of toxicity such as nausea, vomiting, visual changes, or arrhythmias.

mechanism: Enhancing potassium efflux and suppressing calcium influx into the cells of the AV node
Osmotic equilibrium, water does not enter or leave the cells
Osmotic equilibrium, water does not enter or leave the cells
Osmotic equilibrium, water does not enter or leave the cells
Water moves into the cell or ICF compartment
Pulls water from the interstitial space into the ECF causing cell shrinkage
Solutions increase the colloidal oncotic pressure, drawing fluid from interstitial space into plasma
Causes reversible inhibition of AChE within the synapse, allowing more ACh to bind to cholinergic receptors and prolonging its effects
indications: Prevention/treatment of urinary retention in postoperative clients
contraindications: Mechanical obstruction of the intestine or urinary tract
education: Signs of therapeutic failure and toxicity

mechanism: Causes reversible inhibition of AChE within the synapse, allowing more ACh to bind to cholinergic receptors and prolonging its effects
indications: Prevention/treatment of urinary retention in postoperative clients
contraindications: Mechanical obstruction of the intestine or urinary tract
education: Signs of therapeutic failure and toxicity

mechanism: Causes reversible inhibition of AChE
indications: To treat overdoses of atropine and other centrally acting anticholinergic drugs
education: Takes 15 days for drug to reach steady state

mechanism: Causes reversible inhibition of AChE
education: Takes 15 days for drug to reach steady state

mechanism: Causes reversible inhibition of AChE
Causes reversible inhibition of AChE
Binds to the NMDA receptor to prevent the central channel from opening, which regulates the influx of calcium and slows intracellular calcium accumulation
indications: Moderate to severe dementia of the Alzheimer’s type
education: Report severe nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss, dehydration, or signs of GI bleeding

mechanism: Exerts a direct inhibitory effect upon the parasympathetic nervous system by blocking muscarinic receptors in the striatum
indications: As adjunct therapy for all forms of parkinsonism
For control of extrapyramidal disorders (except tardive dyskinesia) caused by neuroleptic drugs
education: Report gastrointestinal complaints, fever, or heat intolerance

mechanism: Exerts a direct inhibitory effect upon the parasympathetic nervous system by blocking muscarinic receptors in the striatum
indications: As adjunct therapy for all forms of parkinsonism
For control of extrapyramidal disorders (except tardive dyskinesia) caused by neuroleptic drugs
education: Report gastrointestinal complaints, fever, or heat intolerance

indications: Reduces symptoms of Parkinson's Disease by increasing dopamine synthesis
education: Report involuntary movements of the face or mouth

mechanism: Selectively binds to dopamine receptor subtype that activates CNS postsynaptic dopamine receptors in the striatum
indications: Used alone in early-stage Parkinson disease
Combined with levodopa in advanced stages of Parkinson disease
interactions: Drugs that can cause QT interval prolongation
education: Be aware of sudden onset of sleep while performing ADLs

education: Monitor for signs and symptoms of liver damage

mechanism: Inhibits GABA receptors in the spinal cord, restricts calcium influx, reduces presynaptic neurotransmitter release in excitatory spinal pathways, decreasing nerve impulse transmission to skeletal muscles and reducing spasticity

education: Monitor for CNS depression of parasympathetic reflexes

mechanism: Blocks beta-1 receptors, decreasing heart rate, myocardial contractility, and blood pressure to reduce cardiac workload
education: Check heart rate before taking; hold if pulse <60 bpm; do not stop medication abruptly.

mechanism: Blocks beta-1 receptors, reducing heart rate and blood pressure to decrease myocardial oxygen demand
education: Monitor pulse and blood pressure; hold if HR <60 bpm; taper dose—do not discontinue abruptly.

mechanism: Inhibits calcium ion influx into vascular smooth muscle, causing vasodilation and decreased peripheral vascular resistance
education: Monitor blood pressure; take with food if GI upset occurs; report edema, dizziness, flushing, or severe headache.

mechanism: Blocks calcium entry into vascular smooth muscle, producing arterial vasodilation and reduced blood pressure
education: Assess blood pressure and heart rate; take with food to minimize GI upset; report dizziness, flushing, headache, or peripheral edema.

mechanism: Inhibits calcium influx into vascular smooth muscle, decreasing systemic vascular resistance
education: Monitor blood pressure and heart rate; report chest pain, palpitations, dizziness; increased risk of myocardial infarction, stroke, and dysrhythmias.

mechanism: Inhibits sodium and chloride reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule, increasing water excretion and lowering blood pressure
education: Take in the morning; monitor daily weight; report weight gain >2 lb/day or >5 lb/week.

mechanism: Blocks sodium and chloride reabsorption in the distal tubule, promoting diuresis and decreased blood pressure
education: Administer early in the day; monitor weight and electrolytes; report rapid weight changes.

mechanism: Inhibits sodium reabsorption in the distal tubule while conserving potassium
education: Take in the morning; monitor weight and potassium levels; report sudden weight changes.

mechanism: Antagonizes aldosterone in the distal nephron, promoting sodium and water excretion while retaining potassium
education: Take in the morning; avoid potassium supplements; monitor daily weight and report rapid changes.

mechanism: Reduces sodium reabsorption in the distal tubule while conserving potassium
education: Administer early in the day; monitor potassium and daily weight; report rapid weight gain or loss.

mechanism: Relaxes vascular smooth muscle, causing vasodilation, reduced preload and afterload, and decreased cardiac workload
education: May cause headaches; monitor blood pressure; avoid erectile dysfunction medications due to risk of severe hypotension.

mechanism: Causes smooth muscle relaxation and vasodilation, lowering cardiac workload and systemic vascular resistance
education: Monitor for headaches and hypotension; do not use with erectile dysfunction medications.

mechanism: Dilates veins and arteries, decreasing cardiac workload, preload, and systemic vascular resistance
education: Monitor blood pressure; may cause headache; avoid erectile dysfunction medications.

mechanism: Directly relaxes vascular smooth muscle, causing arterial and venous dilation, lowering blood pressure and cardiac workload
education: Monitor BP continuously; may cause headaches; avoid erectile dysfunction medications due to risk of severe hypotension.

mechanism: Blocks angiotensin II receptors and inhibits neprilysin, increasing natriuretic peptides and reducing cardiac workload
contraindications: History of angioedema with ACE inhibitor or ARB
education: Avoid potassium-rich foods and salt substitutes; report cough, angioedema, or signs of anaphylaxis.

mechanism: Blocks aldosterone at mineralocorticoid receptors in the nephron, promoting sodium and water excretion while conserving potassium
indications: Edema associated with hepatic cirrhosis or nephrotic syndrome
education: Monitor potassium levels closely; risk for hyperkalemia; report palpitations or muscle weakness.

mechanism: Inhibits SGLT2 in the proximal renal tubules, reducing glucose and sodium reabsorption and promoting glucosuria and diuresis
contraindications: Severe renal impairment, end-stage renal disease, or dialysis
education: Monitor hydration and blood pressure; risk of hypotension with volume depletion; report dizziness or signs of dehydration.

mechanism: Blocks SGLT2 in the proximal tubule, promoting glucose and sodium excretion, lowering blood glucose and reducing cardiac preload
contraindications: Severe renal impairment, end-stage renal disease, or dialysis
education: Assess hydration and blood pressure; risk of hypotension with hypovolemia; report dizziness or excessive urination.

mechanism: Inhibits sodium and chloride reabsorption in the loop of Henle, promoting water excretion
education: Take in the morning; eat potassium-rich foods; monitor daily weight; report weight gain >2 lb/day or >5 lb/week.

mechanism: Blocks sodium and chloride reabsorption in the loop of Henle, increasing urine output and lowering blood pressure
education: Administer early in the day; consume potassium-rich foods; monitor weight daily; report rapid weight changes.

mechanism: Inhibits sodium and chloride reabsorption in the loop of Henle, promoting diuresis and reducing fluid overload
education: Take in the morning; eat potassium-rich foods; monitor daily weight; report weight gain >2 lb/day or >5 lb/week.

mechanism: Inhibits sodium and chloride reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule, increasing water excretion and lowering blood pressure
education: Take early in the morning; monitor weight and electrolytes; report weight gain >2 lb/day or >5 lb/week.

mechanism: Blocks sodium and chloride reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule, increasing diuresis and lowering blood pressure
education: Administer early in the day; monitor weight and electrolytes; report rapid weight changes.

mechanism: Inhibits sodium and chloride reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule, promoting water excretion and lowering blood pressure
education: Take early in the morning; monitor weight and electrolytes; report weight gain >2 lb/day or >5 lb/week.

mechanism: Hydralazine relaxes arteriolar smooth muscle causing vasodilation; isosorbide dinitrate releases nitric oxide, promoting venous and arterial dilation and reducing cardiac workload
indications: Adjunct treatment for heart failure in self-identified Black patients or those intolerant to standard therapy
contraindications: Concurrent use of phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5) inhibitors
education: Monitor blood pressure; risk for hypotension; do not use with erectile dysfunction medications.

mechanism: Blocks hyperpolarization-activated cyclic nucleotide-gated (HCN) channels in the sinoatrial node, slowing heart rate without affecting contractility
indications: Stable heart failure with ejection fraction ≤35% to reduce risk of hospitalization
education: Monitor heart rate; report dizziness, lightheadedness, or irregular heartbeat; avoid grapefruit juice.

mechanism: Potentiates antithrombin III, inactivating thrombin (IIa) and factor Xa
Directly inhibits thrombin (IIa)
Reversibly inhibits thrombin
Enhances antithrombin III, primarily inhibiting factor Xa
Potentiates antithrombin III to inhibit factor Xa
Inhibits vitamin K epoxide reductase, decreasing factors II, VII, IX, X
Selectively inhibits factor Xa
Inhibits factor Xa, reducing thrombin generation
Inhibits factor Xa
Directly inhibits thrombin (IIa)
Binds and neutralizes heparin
Restores synthesis of vitamin K–dependent clotting factors
education: High doses may cause warfarin resistance

mechanism: Inhibits COX-1 in platelets, decreasing thromboxane A2 and platelet aggregation
indications: Primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease
education: Recognize signs and symptoms of bleeding

mechanism: Irreversibly inhibits platelet activation by blocking the P2Y12 ADP receptor
indications: Secondary prevention of MI and stroke
education: Recognize signs and symptoms of bleeding

mechanism: Irreversibly inhibits platelet activation by blocking the P2Y12 ADP receptor
education: Recognize signs and symptoms of bleeding

mechanism: Reversibly inhibits platelet activation by blocking the P2Y12 ADP receptor
education: Recognize signs and symptoms of bleeding

education: Recognize signs and symptoms of bleeding

mechanism: Blocks glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptors, preventing platelet aggregation
education: Recognize signs and symptoms of bleeding

mechanism: Converts plasminogen to plasmin, which breaks down clot-bound fibrin
contraindications: Recent intracranial or intraspinal surgery or serious head trauma
education: Recognize signs and symptoms of bleeding

contraindications: Recent intracranial or intraspinal surgery or serious head trauma
education: Recognize signs and symptoms of bleeding

mechanism: Inhibits HMG-CoA reductase, decreasing hepatic cholesterol synthesis
education: Report signs and symptoms of myositis or rhabdomyolysis

mechanism: Binds to PCSK9, preventing LDL receptor degradation and increasing LDL clearance
education: Report unexplained muscle pain or weakness

mechanism: Binds to PCSK9, preventing LDL receptor degradation and increasing LDL clearance
education: Report unexplained muscle pain or weakness

mechanism: Prevents hepatic synthesis of PCSK9 via RNA interference
education: Administer subcutaneously with initial dose, repeat at 3 months, then every 6 months

mechanism: Binds bile acids in the intestine, reducing absorption and decreasing available bile acids
education: Give other medications 1 hour before or 4-6 hours after cholestyramine

mechanism: Binds bile acids in the intestine, reducing absorption and decreasing available bile acids
indications: Blood sugar reduction in type 2 diabetes
education: Give other medications 1 hour before or 4-6 hours after colesevelam

mechanism: Binds bile acids in the intestine, reducing absorption and decreasing available bile acids
education: Give other medications 1 hour before or 4-6 hours after colestipol

mechanism: Activates PPARs to increase triglyceride breakdown
education: Report signs and symptoms of muscle-related adverse effects

mechanism: Activates PPARs to increase triglyceride breakdown
education: Report signs and symptoms of muscle-related adverse effects

mechanism: May increase lipoprotein lipase activity or enhance removal and reduce synthesis of LDL-cholesterol
education: Avoid using flush-free niacin for lipid management

mechanism: Inhibits the Niemann-Pick C1-Like 1 cholesterol transporter, reducing intestinal cholesterol absorption
contraindications: Active liver disease including unexplained persistent elevations in hepatic transaminases
education: Monitor for muscle-related events if combined with statins

mechanism: Binds to alpha- and beta-adrenergic receptors, stimulating the sympathetic nervous system, increasing heart rate, blood pressure, and bronchodilation
Stimulates dopaminergic, beta-1, and alpha receptors depending on dose, increasing cardiac output and vasoconstriction
education: Monitor BP, urine output, peripheral perfusion
Risk of peripheral ischemia in vascular disease

mechanism: Directly stimulates beta-1 receptors, increasing contractility and heart rate
indications: Short-term inotropic support for cardiac decompensation
education: Do not mix with other IV drugs
Monitor HR, BP, and cardiac output

mechanism: Directly stimulates beta receptors in the lungs, causing smooth muscle dilation and airway opening
education: May cause paradoxical bronchospasm, tachycardia, or immediate hypersensitivity reaction
Monitor respiratory status and heart rate

mechanism: Stimulates alpha- and beta-adrenergic receptors, increasing blood pressure, heart rate, and contractility
Antagonizes histamine H1 receptor sites, hindering histamine effects
education: Avoid in older clients due to anticholinergic effects

mechanism: Blocks histamine at H1 receptor sites
education: Can cause drowsiness, sedation, dry mouth, and insomnia

mechanism: Blocks histamine at H1 receptor sites
education: Can cause drowsiness, sedation, dry mouth, and insomnia

mechanism: Blocks histamine at H1 receptor sites

mechanism: Inhibits peripheral H1 receptors
education: Can cause fatigue, dizziness, nausea, and insomnia

mechanism: Causes vasoconstriction of nasal mucosa to relieve congestion
indications: Nasal congestion from colds, allergies, or respiratory conditions

mechanism: Acts on adrenergic receptors to produce vasoconstriction, shrinking nasal mucosa
indications: Relief of nasal congestion from colds, flu, or allergies
education: Report if symptoms not relieved within 1 week

mechanism: Acts on adrenergic receptors to produce vasoconstriction, shrinking nasal mucosa
indications: Relief of nasal congestion from colds, flu, or allergies
education: Used in patients with high blood pressure

mechanism: Acts on the cough center in the medulla to suppress the cough reflex
education: Report cough lasting >1 week or with other symptoms
Use caution due to opioid effects

mechanism: Thought to act on the brainstem site that gates the cough reflex
education: Report cough lasting >1 week or with other symptoms
Do not chew or dissolve capsules

mechanism: Thought to act on the brainstem site that gates the cough reflex
education: Report cough lasting >1 week or with other symptoms

mechanism: Increases production of respiratory tract fluids to liquefy mucus
indications: Productive coughs where airway clearance of mucus is needed
education: Increase fluids to help loosen secretions
Report if cough persists or worsens

mechanism: Reduces viscosity of pulmonary secretions
indications: Adjunctive therapy for pneumonia, bronchitis, and cystic fibrosis
education: Report if symptoms last >1 week, worsen, or are accompanied by other symptoms
Use as directed for pulmonary conditions

education: Report worsening symptoms including shortness of breath, cough, chest tightness, and wheezing

education: Report worsening symptoms including shortness of breath, cough, chest tightness, and wheezing

mechanism: Relaxes bronchial smooth muscle by stimulating beta-2 receptors and stimulates alpha- and beta-adrenergic receptors in the sympathetic nervous system
education: Can cause increased heart rate and blood pressure, insomnia, and tremors

indications: Relief of acute asthmatic symptoms when combined with albuterol
education: Report worsening symptoms including shortness of breath, cough, chest tightness, and wheezing

education: Take as prescribed without skipping doses or stopping therapy
